abstract: The first full ichthyosaur fossil was thought lost to the ravages of World War II. But researchers recently identified a copy, then more started to emerge.
snippet: The first full ichthyosaur fossil was thought lost to the ravages of World War II. But researchers recently identified a copy, then more started to emerge.
lead_paragraph: In May 1941, the Royal College of Surgeons in London was bombed during a Nazi air raid. Among the specimens lost from its museum collection was a skeleton of an ichthyosaur — an extinct marine reptile that appeared millions of years before dinosaurs laid their first footprints on prehistoric soil.

headline.main: Shattered by Nazi Bombs, a Fossil’s Lost Copies Are Just Being Found

abstract: In a study of mice, researchers worked out a neural pathway that could help researchers alleviate nausea symptoms from chemotherapy drugs.
snippet: In a study of mice, researchers worked out a neural pathway that could help researchers alleviate nausea symptoms from chemotherapy drugs.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who’s had a shady oyster or a mushroom soup that didn’t sit well remembers the ominous queasiness heralding impending bad times. Bacteria release toxins that start the body’s process of speedily evacuating the contents of the stomach. It’s a protective mechanism of sorts — getting rid of the invaders en masse is probably helpful in the long term, even if it’s unpleasant in the short. But it has remained something of a mystery how the brain gets the alarm signal, then sends another one to tell the stomach to initiate a technicolor yawn.

headline.main: How Brains Send a Signal That It’s Time to Vomit

lead_paragraph: For 4,500 years, the pyramids of Giza have loomed over the western bank of the Nile River as a geometric mountain chain. lead_paragraph: One of nature’s most intense spectacles can be tamed with humble sea salt, the same stuff that graces some dinner tables. Researchers recently found that the frequency of lightning decreases by up to 90 percent in the presence of salty sea spray. That makes sense based on how electric fields build up within clouds, the team proposes. These new results, reported this month in the journal Nature Communications, help explain why thunderstorms occur much less frequently over the ocean than over land.

abstract: With a one-of-a-kind museum specimen, researchers recreated the chirp of ancient cricket relatives that droned alongside the dinosaurs.
snippet: With a one-of-a-kind museum specimen, researchers recreated the chirp of ancient cricket relatives that droned alongside the dinosaurs.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s a cicada’s earsplitting drone, a bee’s blaring buzz or a cricket’s incessant chirp, insects are a staple of summer’s score. And arthropods have been making a racket for hundreds of millions of years. One of the noisier groups has been the Prophalangopsidae, a suite of singing insects that went mainstream during the Jurassic period when some 100 species clamored about. While related to modern crickets and katydids, these ancient arthropods left few direct descendants, making it difficult to decipher what these Mesozoic maestros sounded like.

headline.main: Modern and Ancient Crickets May Sing the Same Song

lead_paragraph: Three mushrooms known as the destroying angel, the deadly dapperling and the funeral bell all have something in common: the fabulously lethal toxin alpha-Amanitin. If you eat one of these mushrooms, symptoms may not appear for several hours. But soon enough, the toxin begins wreaking havoc on your body’s ability to transcribe genes. By the fourth day or so after consumption, your liver and kidneys begin to fail. After about a week, you may well die.

headline.main: These Mushrooms Borrowed the Same Deadly Toxin From a Mysterious Source

abstract: The tiny, iridescent parasitoid wasp is the latest insect shown to be a cryptic complex of genetically distinct species.
snippet: The tiny, iridescent parasitoid wasp is the latest insect shown to be a cryptic complex of genetically distinct species.
lead_paragraph: The tiny, iridescent Ormyrus labotus always seemed suspicious for a parasitoid wasp. It wasn’t the wasp’s striking beauty — wasps can be conventionally attractive, too — but its life strategy. Parasitoid wasps lay their eggs on or inside other insects and arthropods, and the larvae eat their way out when they hatch. Each parasitoid wasp species tends to prefer one or a few hosts. But Ormyrus labotus had been observed laying its eggs in more than 65 different species of insects — far more than one or a few.

abstract: For the past year, scientists have been looking for the source of strange coronavirus sequences that have appeared in the city’s wastewater.

lead_paragraph: Last January, a team of researchers searching for the coronavirus in New York City’s wastewater spotted something strange in their samples. The viral fragments they found had a unique constellation of mutations that had never been reported before in human patients — a potential sign of a new, previously undetected variant.

headline.main: In New York City Sewage, a Mysterious Coronavirus Signal
headline.print_headline: The Strange Coronavirus in New York’s Sewage

abstract: Two early recipients of CAR T immunotherapy were free of a blood cancer nearly a decade after receiving the therapy.
snippet: Two early recipients of CAR T immunotherapy were free of a blood cancer nearly a decade after receiving the therapy.
lead_paragraph: Doug Olson was feeling kind of tired in 1996. When a doctor examined him she frowned. “I don’t like the feel of those lymph nodes,” she said, poking his neck. She ordered a biopsy. The result was terrifying. He had chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a blood cancer that mostly strikes older people and accounts for about a quarter of new cases of leukemia.

headline.main: A Cancer Treatment Makes Leukemia Vanish, but Creates More Mysteries
headline.print_headline: Potential Leukemia Cure Leads to New Mysteries

abstract: The Trojan asteroid 2020 XL5, which follows the same path around the sun as our planet, was revealed only after a decade of searching.
snippet: The Trojan asteroid 2020 XL5, which follows the same path around the sun as our planet, was revealed only after a decade of searching.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers have discovered a captive asteroid shadowing Earth in its orbit.

headline.main: Astronomers Find a New Asteroid Sharing Earth’s Orbit
headline.print_headline: In Our Orbit; Asteroid 2020 XL5 Is Shadowing Us, But Only for Another 4,000 Years

abstract: New research aims to shed light on the social habits of the popular, but often misunderstood, animal.
snippet: New research aims to shed light on the social habits of the popular, but often misunderstood, animal.
lead_paragraph: FALMOUTH, Maine — Groundhog Day may be a tongue-in-cheek holiday, but it remains the one day earmarked in the United States for an animal: Marmota monax, the largest and most widely distributed of the marmot genus, found munching on flowering plants — or, at this time of year, snuggling underground — from Alabama to Alaska.

headline.main: Groundhogs Emerge From the Scientific Shadows
headline.print_headline: Out From The Shadows

byline.original: By Brandon Keim and Greta Rybus

abstract: James M. Vaughn Jr., wielding a fortune, argues that he brought about the Fermat breakthrough after the best and brightest had failed for centuries to solve the puzzle.
snippet: James M. Vaughn Jr., wielding a fortune, argues that he brought about the Fermat breakthrough after the best and brightest had failed for centuries to solve the puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Fermat’s last theorem, a riddle put forward by one of history’s great mathematicians, had baffled experts for more than 300 years. Then a genius toiled in secret for seven years to solve it, according to the usual narrative. That shy Englishman, Andrew Wiles, made his feat public in the early 1990s and amassed a glittering array of tributes. In 2016, he won the Abel Prize, math’s top award. It came with a $700,000 purse.

headline.main: The Texas Oil Heir Who Took On Math’s Impossible Dare
headline.print_headline: A Patron’s Vital Spark Revived a Math Quest

abstract: A mutated version of the Omicron variant could slow the steep decline in cases, but it is not likely to change the overall course of the pandemic, scientists said.
snippet: A mutated version of the Omicron variant could slow the steep decline in cases, but it is not likely to change the overall course of the pandemic, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, headlines about a “stealth” Omicron variant have conjured the notion that a villainous new form of the coronavirus is secretly creating a disastrous new wave of Covid.

headline.main: ‘Stealth’ Variant No Cause for Alarm, but Could Slow Case Decline

abstract: Recordings in seas off Australia proved that the predatory prowess of killer whales is inescapable, even for the adults of the largest species that ever lived.
snippet: Recordings in seas off Australia proved that the predatory prowess of killer whales is inescapable, even for the adults of the largest species that ever lived.
lead_paragraph: In March 2019, scientists studying whales near Southwestern Australia stumbled upon a supersize spectacle that few had seen before — a pod of orcas viciously attacking a blue whale.

headline.main: Orcas Are Able to Kill and Eat Blue Whales, Scientists Confirm
headline.print_headline: Killer Whales Live Up to Their Name

abstract: A study shows that there is a way to successfully transplant burrowing owls to new habitats when developers build over their homes.
snippet: A study shows that there is a way to successfully transplant burrowing owls to new habitats when developers build over their homes.
lead_paragraph: As far as wild animals go, the western burrowing owl is a tolerant neighbor to humans. When new houses and roads are built next to the tunnels that they call home, these owls put up with the noise and carry on hunting the insects and rodents that they eat. But the owls are increasingly on a collision course with humanity.

headline.main: Two Simple Tricks That Help Owls Stay in Their New Homes
headline.print_headline: Hootingville; To Make Owls Feel at Home,  Building a Potemkin Village Out of Color and Sound

abstract: New research finds a mutation that suggests the more diminutive canines’ DNA dates back to ancient wolves.
snippet: New research finds a mutation that suggests the more diminutive canines’ DNA dates back to ancient wolves.
lead_paragraph: Big dogs get all the glory. I don’t have a peer-reviewed paper to prove it, but I can quote the greatest country singer of all time, Hank Williams, who is certainly some kind of authority.

headline.main: In Dog DNA, Small Size Has an Ancient Pedigree
headline.print_headline: Small Size Has Ancient Pedigree in Dog DNA

abstract: Scientists describe a process by which African clawed frogs can regrow an imperfect but functional lost limb.
snippet: Scientists describe a process by which African clawed frogs can regrow an imperfect but functional lost limb.
lead_paragraph: African clawed frogs are masters of putting themselves back together, handily regenerating lost tails and hind limbs, when they are tadpoles. But these powers dim with maturity. Wait for an adult frog to regrow a lopped-off limb and you’ll see only a tapered spike, more like a talon than a leg.

headline.main: Frogs Without Legs Regrow Leglike Limbs in New Experiment
headline.print_headline: Back on Their Feet; How Frogs Without Legs Find Their Lost Limbs

abstract: Scientists traced how a mouse’s brain gets the signal that it had enough to drink. Something similar may happen in humans.
snippet: Scientists traced how a mouse’s brain gets the signal that it had enough to drink. Something similar may happen in humans.
lead_paragraph: Few pleasures compare to a long cool drink on a hot day. As a glass of water or other tasty drink makes its way to your digestive tract, your brain is tracking it — but how? Scientists have known for some time that thirst is controlled by neurons that send an alert to put down the glass when the right amount has been guzzled. What precisely tells them that it is time, though, is still a bit mysterious.

headline.main: Your Body’s Thirst Messenger Is in an Unexpected Place
headline.print_headline: Bottoms Up; Letting the Brain Know When Your Thirst Is Quenched

abstract: If further study confirms the findings, they could lead to ways to prevent and treat the complex condition.
snippet: If further study confirms the findings, they could lead to ways to prevent and treat the complex condition.
lead_paragraph: It is one of many mysteries about long Covid: Who is more prone to developing it? Are some people more likely than others to experience physical, neurological or cognitive symptoms that can emerge, or linger for, months after their coronavirus infections have cleared?

headline.main: New Research Hints at 4 Factors That May Increase Chances of Long Covid
headline.print_headline: New Research Hints at 4 Factors That May Increase Chances of Long Covid

abstract: Gang Chen was arrested a year ago on charges of hiding his links to China. The charges were dismissed, but he said the damage — to him, and to American science — has lingered.
snippet: Gang Chen was arrested a year ago on charges of hiding his links to China. The charges were dismissed, but he said the damage — to him, and to American science — has lingered.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When Gang Chen returned to his laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Friday, the day after the government had dismissed charges of lying on grant applications, he was surrounded by well-wishers, offering hugs and congratulations.

headline.main: ‘In the End, You’re Treated Like a Spy,’ Says M.I.T. Scientist
headline.print_headline: M.I.T. Scientist Says He Was ‘Treated Like a Spy’

abstract: By playing a variety of recordings of “wheeze honks” to pods of hippopotamuses, researchers began to decipher how the animals communicate with one another.
snippet: By playing a variety of recordings of “wheeze honks” to pods of hippopotamuses, researchers began to decipher how the animals communicate with one another.
lead_paragraph: Hippopotamuses are some of the most unfriendly creatures in the animal kingdom.

headline.main: To Hippos, a Wheeze and a Honk Mean More Than Just ‘Hello!’
headline.print_headline: Heavy Hitter; If You Hear a Hippo Honking, Best Give It the Right of Way

abstract: Thirteen of Omicron’s mutations should have hurt the variant’s chances of survival. Instead, they worked together to make it thrive.
snippet: Thirteen of Omicron’s mutations should have hurt the variant’s chances of survival. Instead, they worked together to make it thrive.
lead_paragraph: As nurses and doctors struggle with a record-breaking wave of Omicron cases, evolutionary biologists are engaged in a struggle of their own: figuring out how this world-dominating variant came to be.

headline.main: Omicron’s Radical Evolution
headline.print_headline: How Omicron’s Mutations Allow It to Thrive

abstract: A study of fossils from Colombia suggests that a prehistoric shellfish hunted prey with remarkably sharp vision.
snippet: A study of fossils from Colombia suggests that a prehistoric shellfish hunted prey with remarkably sharp vision.
lead_paragraph: Modern, adult crabs are not renowned for their swimming ability or their vision. They scuttle across the floors of silent seas, hardly reliant on small eyes as they scavenge or graze.

headline.main: This Ancient Crab Had Unusually Huge Eyes
headline.print_headline: Visionary Shellfish: In an Ancient Crab, Eyes Worth Taking a Look At

abstract: A preponderance of boulder tracks on the red planet may be evidence of recent seismic activity.
snippet: A preponderance of boulder tracks on the red planet may be evidence of recent seismic activity.
lead_paragraph: If a rock falls on Mars, and no one is there to see it, does it leave a trace? Yes, and it’s a beautiful herringbone-like pattern, new research reveals. Scientists have now spotted thousands of tracks on the red planet created by tumbling boulders. Delicate chevron-shaped piles of Martian dust and sand frame the tracks, the team showed, and most fade over the course of a few years.

headline.main: Bouncing Boulders Point to Quakes on Mars
headline.print_headline: Martian Earthquakes: On the Red Planet, the Rocks May Not Be Through Bouncing

abstract: Some volunteers for biobanks, which collect genetic information to study health across populations, have been surprised to be informed they carry risky mutations.
snippet: Some volunteers for biobanks, which collect genetic information to study health across populations, have been surprised to be informed they carry risky mutations.
lead_paragraph: Marin Konstadt, visiting family in Florida, was at the opera in 2020 when she got a call on her cellphone. She called back at intermission. The caller, a genetics specialist at a hospital, had some important news for her. She has a genetic variant that can increase her disease risk. Did she want to know more?

headline.main: Their DNA Hides a Warning, but They Don’t Want to Know What It Says
headline.print_headline: Their DNA Holds a Warning, But They Don’t Want to Know

abstract: Scientists have discovered a new anatomical structure that allows lunge-feeding whales to take in massive amounts of water without choking.
snippet: Scientists have discovered a new anatomical structure that allows lunge-feeding whales to take in massive amounts of water without choking.
lead_paragraph: To capture prey, humpbacks, minkes and other whales use a tactic called lunge feeding. They accelerate — their mouths open to nearly 90 degrees — and engulf a volume of water large enough to fill their entire bodies. “It’s crazy. Imagine putting an entire human inside your mouth,” said Kelsey Gil, a zoologist studying whale physiology at the University of British Columbia.

headline.main: Why Whales Don’t Choke
headline.print_headline: No-Choke Anatomy: Why Whales Have No Need for the Heimlich Maneuver

abstract: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.
snippet: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Federal prosecutors on Thursday dropped the government’s charges against Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in an embarrassing setback to the government’s drive to crack down on economic and scientific espionage by China.

headline.main: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links
headline.print_headline: M.I.T. Professor Won’t Be Tried In China Case

byline.original: By Ellen Barry and Katie Benner

abstract: At the edge of a vast region devoid of gas and dust, scientists find an explanation for “how all nearby star formation began.”
snippet: At the edge of a vast region devoid of gas and dust, scientists find an explanation for “how all nearby star formation began.”
lead_paragraph: Just a bit too late for New Year celebrations, astronomers have discovered that the Milky Way galaxy, our home, is, like champagne, full of bubbles.

headline.main: A New Map of the Sun’s Local Bubble
headline.print_headline: Where Our Bubble Ends, Our Understanding Begins

abstract: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.
snippet: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most well-known takeaways of the pandemic: Men die of Covid-19 more often than women do.

headline.main: Why Are Men More Likely to Die of Covid? It’s Complicated.
headline.print_headline: Why Are Men More Likely to Die From Covid?

abstract: It is too soon to know, scientists say, but mild initial illness may not signal reduced risk.
snippet: It is too soon to know, scientists say, but mild initial illness may not signal reduced risk.
lead_paragraph: Many public health officials have taken heart in early evidence that suggests infections from the Omicron variant tend to cause less severe illness than other versions of the coronavirus. But another important question looms: whether infection with Omicron, including breakthrough cases in vaccinated people, can result in long Covid — the constellation of physical, neurological and cognitive symptoms that can last for months and impair people’s daily lives.

headline.main: Can Omicron Cause Long Covid?
headline.print_headline: Can the Omicron Variant Cause Long Covid?

abstract: The number of people who try suicide has risen steadily in the U.S. But despite gains in health coverage, nearly half are not getting mental health treatment.
snippet: The number of people who try suicide has risen steadily in the U.S. But despite gains in health coverage, nearly half are not getting mental health treatment.
lead_paragraph: Suicide attempts in the United States showed a “substantial and alarming increase” over the last decade, but one number remained the same, a new study has found: Year in and year out, about 40 percent of people who had recently tried suicide said they were not receiving mental health services.

headline.main: Survey of Americans Who Attempted Suicide Finds Many Aren’t Getting Care
headline.print_headline: Americans Who Attempted Suicide Lacked Adequate Care, Study Says

abstract: The stunning Covid vaccines manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna drew upon long-buried discoveries made in the hopes of ending past epidemics.
snippet: The stunning Covid vaccines manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna drew upon long-buried discoveries made in the hopes of ending past epidemics.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of miles from Dr. Barney Graham’s lab in Bethesda, Md., a frightening new coronavirus had jumped from camels to humans in the Middle East, killing one out of every three people infected. An expert on the world’s most intractable viruses, Dr. Graham had been working for months to develop a vaccine, but had gotten nowhere.

headline.main: Halting Progress and Happy Accidents: How mRNA Vaccines Were Made
headline.print_headline: Decades of Discoveries Before ‘Miraculous’ Sprint to a Vaccine

byline.original: By Gina Kolata and Benjamin Mueller

abstract: A new study finds the first known instance of a human-engineered hybrid, bred from a donkey and a Syrian wild ass 4,500 years ago.
snippet: A new study finds the first known instance of a human-engineered hybrid, bred from a donkey and a Syrian wild ass 4,500 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In ancient Mesopotamia 4,500 years ago, long before horses arrived in the region, another spirited member of the equine family, the kunga, took a starring role in pulling four-wheeled wagons into battle.

headline.main: The Kunga Was a Status Symbol Long Before the Thoroughbred
headline.print_headline: A Status Symbol Before Thoroughbreds

abstract: As Omicron spreads, some experts are calling for a switch to saliva-based tests, which may detect infections days earlier than nasal swabs do.
snippet: As Omicron spreads, some experts are calling for a switch to saliva-based tests, which may detect infections days earlier than nasal swabs do.
lead_paragraph: Jan. 20, 2022: This article was updated to include new data about the sensitivity of throat swabs.

headline.main: For Coronavirus Testing, the Nose May Not Always Be Best
headline.print_headline: For Virus Testing, Saliva May Be a Better Option

abstract: In a study of members of the Armed Forces, people who developed multiple sclerosis first had Epstein-Barr virus.
snippet: In a study of members of the Armed Forces, people who developed multiple sclerosis first had Epstein-Barr virus.
lead_paragraph: For decades, researchers have suspected that people infected with an exceedingly common virus, Epstein-Barr, might be more likely to develop multiple sclerosis, a neurological illness that affects a million people in the United States. Now, a team of researchers reports what some say is the most compelling evidence yet of a strong link between the two diseases.

headline.main: Common Virus May Play Role in Debilitating Neurological Illness
headline.print_headline: Study Suggests Epstein-Barr Virus Is Linked to Multiple Sclerosis Risk

abstract: Researchers say the human concepts of intergenerational wealth and inequality are useful for studying some animals’ behavior.
snippet: Researchers say the human concepts of intergenerational wealth and inequality are useful for studying some animals’ behavior.
lead_paragraph: Some North American red squirrels are born with a silver spoon in their mouths. They live in pine forests where the adults defend caches of food. Without a cache of their own, many baby squirrels won’t survive the winter. But each year, some squirrel mothers abandon their territory, bequeathing all their food to one or more babies who stay behind. These young squirrels are much more likely to survive until the spring.

headline.main: Checking Privilege in the Animal Kingdom
headline.print_headline: Some Animals Get A Head Start, Too

abstract: A close examination of 11 clitorises from common bottlenose dolphins suggests the female cetaceans experience pleasure during frequent sexual activity.
snippet: A close examination of 11 clitorises from common bottlenose dolphins suggests the female cetaceans experience pleasure during frequent sexual activity.
lead_paragraph: Common bottlenose dolphins have sex frequently — very likely multiple times in a day. Copulation lasts only a few seconds, but social sex, which is used to maintain social bonds, can last much longer, happen more frequently and involve myriad heterosexual and homosexual pairings of dolphins and their body parts. Anything is possible, and, as new research suggests, probably pleasurable for swimmers of both sexes.

headline.main: Uncovering Mysteries of Female Dolphin Sexual Anatomy
headline.print_headline: Maybe She Has Good Reason to Smile

abstract: Recent research highlights the use of letterlocking techniques by Queen Elizabeth, Catherine de’ Medici and Mary Queen of Scots.
snippet: Recent research highlights the use of letterlocking techniques by Queen Elizabeth, Catherine de’ Medici and Mary Queen of Scots.
lead_paragraph: To safeguard the most important royal correspondence against snoops and spies in the 16th century, writers employed a complicated means of security. They’d fold the letter, then cut a dangling strip, using that as an improvised thread to sew stitches that locked the letter and turned the flat writing paper into its own envelope. To get inside, a spy would have to snip the lock open, an act impossible to go undetected.

headline.main: How European Royals Once Shared Their Most Important Secrets
headline.print_headline: How the Royals Once Shared Their Secrets

lead_paragraph: Children who have recovered from Covid-19 appear to be at significantly increased risk of developing Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.

headline.main: Covid may raise the risk of diabetes in children, C.D.C. researchers reported.

abstract: The find suggests overlooked rocks across the continent may contain more fossilized surprises.
snippet: The find suggests overlooked rocks across the continent may contain more fossilized surprises.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s Central Tablelands, hundreds of miles northwest of Sydney, are dominated today by grasses and spindly trees. But scientists recently discovered that some of the area’s rusted rocks conceal traces of the lush rainforests that covered the area 15 million years ago during the Miocene Epoch.

headline.main: Fossils of a Prehistoric Rainforest Hide in Australia’s Rusted Rocks
headline.print_headline: In Australian Fossils, a Rainforest Beckons

abstract: In a lab with lasers, scientists worked out a multi-chromatic mystery observed around the solar system.
snippet: In a lab with lasers, scientists worked out a multi-chromatic mystery observed around the solar system.
lead_paragraph: The head of a comet often glows green; the tail mostly does not. That includes Comet Leonard, which made its closest pass to the sun on Monday and is heading away again.

headline.main: Why a Comet’s Head Is Green, but Its Tail Is Not
headline.print_headline: Turning Tail: Why Only a Comet’s Head  Is Given the Green Light

abstract: Everyone should get a booster shot. In the long run, though, doses every few months aren’t a viable public health strategy, scientists say.
snippet: Everyone should get a booster shot. In the long run, though, doses every few months aren’t a viable public health strategy, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, just two doses of a Covid-19 vaccine — or even one, in the case of Johnson & Johnson’s formulation — were thought to offer sufficient protection against the coronavirus.

headline.main: Will ‘Forever Boosting’ Beat the Coronavirus?
headline.print_headline: Should We Expect Another Shot Every Few Months? No.

abstract: A close examination of human skin found that each pore had a single variety of bacteria living inside.
snippet: A close examination of human skin found that each pore had a single variety of bacteria living inside.
lead_paragraph: Your skin is home to a thousand kinds of bacteria, and the ways they contribute to healthy skin are still largely mysterious. This mystery may be getting even more complex: In a paper published Thursday in the journal Cell Host & Microbe, researchers studying the many varieties of Cutibacterium acnes bacteria on 16 human volunteers found that each pore was a world unto itself. Every pore contained just a single type of C. acnes.

headline.main: Every Pore on Your Face Is a Walled Garden
headline.print_headline: Pore Worlds: These Bacteria Have Become Accustomed to Your Face

abstract: Scientists chart how a battle between fungus and bacteria living on the skin of hedgehogs led to the emergence of a strain of MRSA that can infect cows and humans.
snippet: Scientists chart how a battle between fungus and bacteria living on the skin of hedgehogs led to the emergence of a strain of MRSA that can infect cows and humans.
lead_paragraph: The tiny, spiny and adorable hedgehog is helping to upend conventional wisdom about the origins of drug-resistant bacterial infections that kill thousands of people each year.

headline.main: Hedgehogs Are a Source of Drug-Resistant Bacteria, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Hedgehog Insights: From Danish Roadkill, a New Theory on the Source of Deadly Infections

snippet: A population of strange canids in Texas could hold the key to reviving the highly endangered red wolf.

abstract: Scientists have described a giant new species of ichthyosaur that evolved its 55-foot-long body size only a few million years after the lizards returned to the seas.
snippet: Scientists have described a giant new species of ichthyosaur that evolved its 55-foot-long body size only a few million years after the lizards returned to the seas.
lead_paragraph: About 246 million years ago, a sea lizard with a skull the size of a grand piano died in the ancient ocean that is now Nevada. It was an ichthyosaur, and its body was most likely the size of a modern sperm whale.

headline.main: This Sea Lizard Had a Grand Piano-Size Head and a Big Appetite
headline.print_headline: Sea Lizard Evolved At Breakneck Speed

abstract: Soccer fans aren’t the only ones on Earth who make waves.
snippet: Soccer fans aren’t the only ones on Earth who make waves.
lead_paragraph: In the sulfur-infused ponds of Tabasco State in Mexico lives a tiny silver slip of a fish, the sulphur molly. Toss in a rock, and you might see a bunch of them dance: The water’s surface will erupt in pale, pulsing waves, spreading through the eerie blue like milk through coffee. Every few seconds, thousands of fish will repeat a quick diving motion to generate the wave, sometimes for up to two minutes.

headline.main: Why These Mexican Fish Do the Wave
headline.print_headline: Why These Mexican Fish Do the Wave

abstract: A jury found the Harvard chemist Charles Lieber guilty of lying to the federal government about his participation in China’s Thousand Talents recruitment program.
snippet: A jury found the Harvard chemist Charles Lieber guilty of lying to the federal government about his participation in China’s Thousand Talents recruitment program.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Charles Lieber, one of the country’s top research chemists, sat miserably in a chair at the Harvard Police Department, trying to explain to two F.B.I. agents why he had agreed to partner with a lesser-known Chinese university in a relationship that had soured and landed him in trouble with the U.S. government.

headline.main: In a Boston Court, a Superstar of Science Falls to Earth
headline.print_headline: Top U.S. Chemist Guilty of Not Disclosing Chinese Ties

abstract: They do seem to offer significant protection against severe illness, but the consequences of rapidly spreading infection worry many public health experts.
snippet: They do seem to offer significant protection against severe illness, but the consequences of rapidly spreading infection worry many public health experts.
lead_paragraph: A growing body of preliminary research suggests the Covid vaccines used in most of the world offer almost no defense against becoming infected by the highly contagious Omicron variant.

headline.main: Most of the World’s Vaccines Likely Won’t Prevent Infection From Omicron
headline.print_headline: Most Shots Used Abroad May Not Halt Omicron

abstract: I.V.F. patients are faced with a growing list of costly “add-ons.” For one such test, some say more robust research is needed to support its effectiveness.
snippet: I.V.F. patients are faced with a growing list of costly “add-ons.” For one such test, some say more robust research is needed to support its effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: For patients undergoing in vitro fertilization, there is a common test to help determine the best time to transfer the embryo for a successful pregnancy. But new research has patients and doctors questioning whether the test — one of a growing number of expensive “add-ons” for I.V.F. patients — is effective for first-time patients.

headline.main: A Popular Test Claims to Boost I.V.F. Success. The Science Is Unclear.
headline.print_headline: The Science Is Unclear on a Popular I.V.F. Test

abstract: The mosquitofish is wreaking havoc on native Australian marine life. In a new study, scientists tried to frighten it with a look-alike of its natural foe.
snippet: The mosquitofish is wreaking havoc on native Australian marine life. In a new study, scientists tried to frighten it with a look-alike of its natural foe.
lead_paragraph: The mosquitofish is not a fussy creature: It can live in filthy bodies of water and has an undiscerning appetite. Larvae? Other fishes’ eggs? Detritus? Delicious. Often, the voracious few-inch creature chomps off the tails of freshwater fish and tadpoles, leaving them to die.

headline.main: How to Scare an Invasive Fish? A Menacing Robot Predator.
headline.print_headline: Frighteningly Effective: Want to Scare Off Invasive Fish?  A Robot Might Do the Trick.

abstract: A species found deep underground in Western Australia shows that “millipede” is not always a misnomer.
snippet: A species found deep underground in Western Australia shows that “millipede” is not always a misnomer.
lead_paragraph: It’s a well-known fact among entomologists that whoever first named the millipede was being a touch dramatic. The name means “thousand-footed,” but no millipede has a thousand feet.

headline.main: At Last, a True Millipede That Actually Has 1,000 Legs or More
headline.print_headline: Finally, a Millipede  True to Its Name

abstract: A new paper posits that the guard hairs of rodents and other small mammals may help sense the heat of predators, though more research is needed.
snippet: A new paper posits that the guard hairs of rodents and other small mammals may help sense the heat of predators, though more research is needed.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough out there for a mouse. Outdoors, its enemies lurk on all sides: owls above, snakes below, weasels around the bend. Indoors, a mouse may find itself targeted by broom-wielding humans or bored cats.

headline.main: A Hair-Raising Hypothesis About Rodent Hair
headline.print_headline: Rodents May Have ‘Infrared Antennae,’ Study Says

abstract: The OSIRIS-REX spacecraft, which collected samples from the asteroid Bennu, would visit a second space rock, Apophis.
snippet: The OSIRIS-REX spacecraft, which collected samples from the asteroid Bennu, would visit a second space rock, Apophis.
lead_paragraph: First it punched an asteroid. Now, a NASA spacecraft’s rampage may continue and it could blast a hole in another space rock.

headline.main: NASA Mission Could Blast an Asteroid That Once Menaced Earth
headline.print_headline: Continuing a Mission To Harass Asteroids

abstract: An Australian researcher argues that the medical community has enshrined placebos as “mysterious and highly effective” in clinical care on the basis of flawed research.
snippet: An Australian researcher argues that the medical community has enshrined placebos as “mysterious and highly effective” in clinical care on the basis of flawed research.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Having worked for decades as a physical therapist and a clinical researcher, Chris Maher knows firsthand how difficult it can be to treat back pain. The condition’s causes are often complex or uncertain, and treatments can be ineffective, even harmful.

headline.main: Doctors Often Prescribe Placebos. But How Well Do They Work?

abstract: The James Webb Space Telescope is endowed with the hopes and trepidations of a generation of astronomers.
snippet: The James Webb Space Telescope is endowed with the hopes and trepidations of a generation of astronomers.
lead_paragraph: What do astronomers eat for breakfast on the day that their $10 billion telescope launches into space? Their fingernails.

headline.main: Why the World’s Astronomers Are Very, Very Anxious Right Now
headline.print_headline: With the Launch Comes the Nerves

abstract: America’s response to the variant highlights both how much progress we have made over the past two years — and how much work remains.
snippet: America’s response to the variant highlights both how much progress we have made over the past two years — and how much work remains.
lead_paragraph: When scientists discovered the highly mutated Omicron variant of the coronavirus last month, it set off an eerily familiar chain of events.

headline.main: Omicron Is a Dress Rehearsal for the Next Pandemic
headline.print_headline: Dress Rehearsals

abstract: Health authorities in Europe are warning of a sharp increase in Omicron cases, adding to an existing surge from the Delta variant.
snippet: Health authorities in Europe are warning of a sharp increase in Omicron cases, adding to an existing surge from the Delta variant.
lead_paragraph: Public health authorities in Denmark and Norway on Monday released grim projections for the coming wave of the Omicron coronavirus variant, predicting that it will dominate both countries in a matter of days. Although scientists don’t yet know how often the variant causes severe disease, they say its rapid rate of spread will lead to an explosion of cases and could potentially increase pressure on hospitals, even if it proves to be mild.

headline.main: Denmark and Norway Predict Drastic Spike in Omicron Cases
headline.print_headline: Denmark and Norway Say Omicron Is Poised To Eclipse Delta Strain

abstract: Some laboratory studies suggest that molnupiravir can insert errors in DNA, which could in theory harm a developing fetus, sperm cells or children.
snippet: Some laboratory studies suggest that molnupiravir can insert errors in DNA, which could in theory harm a developing fetus, sperm cells or children.
lead_paragraph: A new Covid-19 pill from Merck has raised hopes that it could transform the landscape of treatment options for Americans at high risk of severe disease at a time when the Omicron variant of the coronavirus is driving a surge of cases in highly vaccinated European countries.

headline.main: Merck’s Covid Pill Might Pose Risks for Pregnant Women
headline.print_headline: As Merck’s Covid Pill Awaits Approval, Some Scientists Worry It Might Alter Human DNA

abstract: Researchers pinpointed the genetic machinery behind some of these tiny creatures’ amazing powers of regeneration.
snippet: Researchers pinpointed the genetic machinery behind some of these tiny creatures’ amazing powers of regeneration.
lead_paragraph: In rivers and streams across the globe lives a tube-shaped carnivore. It paralyzes and captures prey with a crown of tentacles, then draws it in through its mouth (which also serves as its anus). This unsettling creature is a hydra, a freshwater-dwelling cnidarian no more than a half-inch long that eats mostly insect larvae and crustaceans. A hydra’s appearance and eating habits alone give it a sci-fi feel, but its ability to regenerate its body — even its head — from only a scrap of tissue or pile of cells raises it to another level.

headline.main: Hydra DNA Reveals There’s More Than One Way to Regrow a Head
headline.print_headline: Losing Their Minds: There’s More Than One Way To Grow Another Head

abstract: Scientists devised a mathematic model that helps explains how Nipponites, some of the wonkiest ammonites, built their shells.
snippet: Scientists devised a mathematic model that helps explains how Nipponites, some of the wonkiest ammonites, built their shells.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen one ammonite, you may think you’ve seen them all. Most of the 10,000 species of the extinct cephalopods sported tightly coiled shells with polite mouthfuls of tentacles.

headline.main: Unraveling How an Extinct Mollusk Got Its Strange Shell
headline.print_headline: An Extinct Mollusk’s Twisty Shell Fascinates

snippet: The research may help explain why people who are overweight and obese have been at higher risk of severe illness and death from Covid.
lead_paragraph: From the start of the pandemic, the coronavirus seemed to target people carrying extra pounds. Patients who were overweight or obese were more likely to develop severe Covid-19 and more likely to die.

headline.main: The Coronavirus Attacks Fat Tissue, Scientists Find

abstract: Scientists who injected idle mice with blood from athletic mice found improvements in learning and memory. The findings could have implications for Alzheimer’s research and beyond.
snippet: Scientists who injected idle mice with blood from athletic mice found improvements in learning and memory. The findings could have implications for Alzheimer’s research and beyond.
lead_paragraph: What if something in the blood of an athlete could boost the brainpower of someone who doesn’t or can’t exercise? Could a protein that gets amplified when people exercise help stave off symptoms of Alzheimer’s and other memory disorders?

headline.main: Can an Athlete’s Blood Enhance Brainpower?
headline.print_headline: Study of Mice Reveals A Boost for Brainpower In the Blood of Athletes

lead_paragraph: If a pancake could dream, it might long for legs so it could jump off your breakfast plate in pursuit of a better, unchewed life.

snippet: A new clinic focuses on patients left grappling with the aftermath of treatment in ways that are rarely appreciated by doctors.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Matthew Curtin learned he had prostate cancer after a routine physical examination in October 2019, when test results indicated there was a problem. A biopsy confirmed the news, and doctors told him that surgery to remove his prostate was the best option.

headline.print_headline: Prostate Cancer and New Care for Gay Men

abstract: Merck and Pfizer will soon debut prescription pills to treat Covid-19. And more drugs are on the way.
snippet: Merck and Pfizer will soon debut prescription pills to treat Covid-19. And more drugs are on the way.
lead_paragraph: As the world worries that the Omicron coronavirus variant may cause a surge of cases and weaken vaccines, drug developers have some encouraging news: Two new Covid-19 pills are coming soon, and are expected to work against all versions of the virus.

headline.main: New Covid Pills Offer Hope as Omicron Looms
headline.print_headline: Help Arrives In Covid-19 Fight

abstract: A survey of more than 80,000 physicians estimated that women make 25 percent less than men over a 40-year career.
snippet: A survey of more than 80,000 physicians estimated that women make 25 percent less than men over a 40-year career.
lead_paragraph: Female doctors make less than their male counterparts starting from their very first days on the job, according to a large new study. Over the course of a 40-year-career, researchers estimated, this pay gap adds up to at least $2 million.

headline.main: Women Earn $2 Million Less Than Men in Their Careers as Doctors
headline.print_headline: Study Finds Pay Gap of 25% for Doctors

abstract: Average blood pressure readings increased as the coronavirus spread, new research suggests. The finding portends medical repercussions far beyond Covid-19.
snippet: Average blood pressure readings increased as the coronavirus spread, new research suggests. The finding portends medical repercussions far beyond Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: Last year was a tough one. Americans grappled with a global pandemic, the loss of loved ones, lockdowns that splintered social networks, stress, unemployment and depression.

headline.main: The Pandemic Has Your Blood Pressure Rising? You’re Not Alone.
headline.print_headline: Does the Pandemic Have Your Blood Pressure Rising? You’re Not Alone.
